title: 109_s956
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jetseta Gage Prevention and Deterrence of Crimes Against Children Act of 2005". Assured punishment for violent crimes against children is outlined in the Act. The "Jetseta Gage Prevention and Deterrence of Crimes Against Children Act of 2005" amends the Special Sentencing Rule in section 3559 of title 18, United States Code, to impose mandatory minimum terms of imprisonment for violent crimes against children under the age of 15. This includes death or life imprisonment for crimes resulting in the death of a child, and life imprisonment for kidnapping, sexual assault, maiming, or serious bodily injury offenses. The "Jetseta Gage Prevention and Deterrence of Crimes Against Children Act of 2005" imposes mandatory minimum terms of imprisonment for violent crimes against children under 15. This includes life imprisonment for crimes resulting in death, and varying terms for bodily injury, weapon use, and other cases. SEC. 3. INCREASED PENALTIES FOR SEXUAL OFFENSES AGAINST CHILDREN. Increased penalties for sexual offenses against children include amending Section 2241(c) of title 18, United States Code to impose a minimum sentence of 30 years or life for aggravated sexual abuse of children. Additionally, Section 2244 of chapter 109A of title 18, United States Code is amended to include abusive sexual contact with children, with specific modifications to subsection (a) and the addition of a new paragraph (2) related to prior offenses under section 2241. Amendments to Section 2245 of title 18, United States Code increase penalties for sexual abuse of children resulting in death, with a minimum sentence of 30 years or life imprisonment. Amendments to Section 2251 of title 18, United States Code increase penalties for sexual exploitation of children, with a minimum sentence of 25 years or life imprisonment. Amendments to Section 2252 of title 18, United States Code increase penalties for activities involving the sexual exploitation of children, with a minimum sentence of 25 years or life imprisonment. Amendments to Section 2252 of title 18, United States Code increase penalties for activities involving child pornography, with a minimum sentence of 25 years or life imprisonment. Amendments to Section 2252 of title 18, United States Code increase penalties for activities involving child pornography, with a minimum sentence of 25 years or life imprisonment. Changes include increasing the maximum imprisonment for certain offenses to 30 years or life. Additionally, penalties for using misleading domain names to direct children to harmful material on the internet are increased to a minimum of 10 years imprisonment. Amendments to Section 2252 of title 18, United States Code increase penalties for activities involving child pornography, with a minimum sentence of 25 years or life imprisonment. Changes include increasing the maximum imprisonment for certain offenses to 30 years or life. Additionally, penalties for using misleading domain names to direct children to harmful material on the internet are increased to a minimum of 10 years imprisonment. In Section 2423, penalties for conduct relating to child prostitution are also increased, with imprisonment ranging from 30 years to life for various offenses. In Section 2252 of title 18, penalties for child pornography offenses are increased to a minimum of 10 years imprisonment and a maximum of 30 years. SEC. 4. ENSURING FAIR AND EXPEDITIOUS FEDERAL COLLATERAL REVIEW OF CONVICTIONS FOR KILLING A CHILD. The "Christy Ann Fornoff Act" limits jurisdiction for considering claims related to judgments or sentences in certain applications, requiring claims to qualify under specific grounds. Applications not filed in district court must be transferred there for review or dismissal, with appeals panels needing authorization for second or successive applications. The "Christy Ann Fornoff Act" sets requirements for habeas corpus applications related to crimes involving the killing of a minor. Any motion for an evidentiary hearing must be filed within 90 days of the State's answer, and granted or denied within 30 days of the opposing party's pleading. The "Christy Ann Fornoff Act" establishes timeframes for evidentiary hearings and final orders in habeas corpus applications related to crimes involving the killing of a minor. Evidentiary hearings must be held within 60-150 days after being granted, and final orders must be issued within 15 months of the State filing its answer or within 60 days of the case being submitted for decision. Failure to comply allows the State to petition the court of appeals for a writ of mandamus. The court of appeals must decide on a petition for a writ of mandamus within 30 days of filing. Requirements for appeals related to habeas corpus orders include a stay upon filing a notice of appeal and a decision within 120 days of the appellee's brief or within the due date if no brief is filed. Following a decision by a panel of the court of appeals, a petition for panel rehearing is not allowed, but rehearing by the court of appeals en banc may be requested. The court of appeals shall decide whether to grant a petition for rehearing en banc within 30 days of filing, unless a response is required. The court of appeals must make a final determination of the appeal within 120 days if rehearing en banc is granted. Failure to comply allows the State to petition the Supreme Court for a writ of mandamus. Time limitations apply to initial and subsequent applications, as well as redeterminations or appeals after a remand. In proceedings following a remand, time limits for further briefing in the district court or court of appeals are specified. Time limits run from the date the remand is ordered if no further briefing is required, otherwise from the date of filing a responsive brief. The time limit for further briefing in court proceedings following a remand is specified to run from the date of filing a responsive brief. Failure to meet time limitations does not grant relief from a judgment or entitle a capital applicant to a stay of execution. Additionally, rights for crime victims in habeas corpus proceedings arising from a State conviction are extended under Section 3771(b) of title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this section apply to cases pending on or after the date of enactment of the Act. Time limits in pending cases will run from the date of enactment if they are based on events prior to that date.
